thread.title: Telegraph Junior Golf 2015: Matthew Fitzpatrick's British Masters win an inspiration for juniors
thread.title_full: Telegraph Junior Golf 2015: Matthew Fitzpatrick's British Masters win an inspiration for juniors - Telegraph

author: Rod Gilmour , Quinta do Lago
title: Telegraph Junior Golf 2015: Matthew Fitzpatrick's British Masters win an inspiration for juniors
text: • Latest Telegraph Junior Ch'ship news • Read how 2014 Telegraph winners fared at BMW Pro-Am Tommy Fleetwood, the world No 62, says that the Telegraph BMW Junior Championships are a “great treat” for the 21 finalists, but wishes that he could have won it during his junior career. Fleetwood, the then-England under-18 captain, was beaten in a play-off at the 2008 finals in Abu Dhabi behind Stiggy Hodgson. It's Am/Am day here at @Quinta_do_Lago pic.twitter.com/DQrTuS2pcv — TelegraphJuniorGolf (@TelegraphJunior) October 13, 2015 Seven years on, and ahead of his appearance at the Portugal Masters, he attended the welcome dinner for the 12 boys and nine girls on the eve of this year’s Championship at Quinta do Lago. “I still speak to the people I played against like Stiggy and Tom Lewis,” Fleetwood said. “It may be a small field but this makes it so competitive. It’s a prestigious event and I wish I could say that I had won it.” The 2015 finals, which this year celebrates its 30th anniversary, couldn’t have been timed better given that Matthew Fitzpatrick, the 2012 Telegraph champion , lifted the British Masters at the weekend. Matt Fitzpatrick and Emily Taylor with their 2012 trophies Fleetwood said that although Fitzpatrick had perhaps “exceeded expectations” in his rising professional career, the success of past Telegraph competitors – 2011 runner-up Jimmy Mullen, for example, was a standout at the Walker Cup, while 2013 girls' champion Alice Hewson has won twice on the collegiate circuit in the last month – was in part down to a transition in English junior golf. “You don’t have players who stay amateur forever now,” he said. “England Golf has tended to players earlier and we are now perhaps the best example of this [in the world].” The 54-hole strokeplay finals get under way on Wednesday morning on Quinta do Lago’s redesigned North Course. Bath’s Jamie Li, below, will be competing in his third straight Finals, while Mark Flynn will be aiming to follow in Fleetwood’s footsteps as a fellow Formby Hall member. Meanwhile, Louisa Brunt returns after finishing fifth last year in the girls’ event. The 21 finalists enjoyed a practice round on Monday before taking part in Tuesday's Am-Am competition. Rain had been forecast but sun and a light wind enveloped the course, making for fine conditions. Follow the latest news, leaderboards , images and build-up to October’s Finals on Twitter @TelegraphJunior and on our Facebook page
